At 02:10 21/09/2004, you wrote:
>If double precision isn't required thats great - my concern is based
>on a number of comments in the book Neural Network and Fuzzy Logic
>Applications by Stephen Welstead concerning precision - most of his
>examples use double precision weight arrays.  In particular he points
>out that double precision is required in applications involving
>chaotic processes.  Pentiums have dedicated double precision floating
>point hardware that is extremely efficient while the majority of
>embedded processors implement single precision floating point in
>software and usually don't support double precision at all.

He may have had good reasons for this, but it sounds like he's missed the 
point about chaos theory...

There's no "cure" for chaotic behaviour and increased precision cannot 
"help" it.  In fact there is _greater_ scope for chaos at higher precision, 
although that cannot be taken as an argument against it, because chaos 
arises as a real feature of the system under study, it's not a side effect 
of precision or any other aspect of how the maths is done.

Neural nets can only be chaotic if there is feedback from later to earlier 
stages.  This may be because the network is recurrent, or it could happen 
if the external application does any thing to feed previous answers back 
into the inputs.

In either case, if you are set on evolving your topology/weights, then 
there's not a lot you can do about it (in a hand-specified system you might 
be able to reduce the magnitude of the feedback and at some point the chaos 
would stop).

> > Are you able to elaborate on the types of problem you're
>considering?
> >
>We are investigating the development of a real time, using ANN based,
>in-scene object recognizer/tracker running on an embedded processor
>(Analog Devices Blackfin) possibly augmented with a floating point co-
>processor (Analog Devices Shark) .  We're just getting starting and
>the threads here have been very helpful.  The show stopper is double
>verse single precision.

The precision of single is 1 in 1000000, so:

1) can a difference of 0.0000001 matter in the inputs?
2) will the output of any node be multiplied by enough (possibly over 
several stages) that a difference of 0.0000001 would matter?

((that last is where chaos can come in, becuase with feedback a difference 
can be multiplied across the same stage over and over again...))

My guess is that single will be fine for you.  If you wanted to save the 
cost of the FPU then you could probably code it in a fixed-point integer 
system, but that will cost more software development time/testing/debugging...

I assume you will prototype on a PC?  Do that in single and when it works 
OK, then worry about the limits of the embedded system...
